leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 98] s 98 Courts powers as to costs (cf Act No 52 1970, section 76; SCR Part 52A, rules 5, 6, 7 and 8; Act No 9 1973, section 148B; Act No 11 1970, section 34)

leg:heading.title: Courts powers as to costs (cf Act No 52 1970, section 76; SCR Part 52A, rules 5, 6, 7 and 8; Act No 9 1973, section 148B; Act No 11 1970, section 34)

p.text: Subject to rules of court and to this or any other Act:
costs are in the discretion of the court, and
the court has full power to determine by whom, to whom and to what extent costs are to be paid, and
the court may order that costs are to be awarded on the ordinary basis or on an indemnity basis.
Subject to rules of court and to this or any other Act, a party to proceedings may not recover costs from any other party otherwise than pursuant to an order of the court.
An order as to costs may be made by the court at any stage of the proceedings or after the conclusion of the proceedings.
In particular, at any time before costs are referred for assessment, the court may make an order to the effect that the party to whom costs are to be paid is to be entitled to:
costs up to, or from, a specified stage of the proceedings, or
a specified proportion of the assessed costs, or
a specified gross sum instead of assessed costs, or
such proportion of the assessed costs as does not exceed a specified amount.

The powers of the court under this section apply in relation to a married woman, whether as party, tutor, relator or otherwise, and this section has effect in addition to, and despite anything in, the Married Persons (Equality of Status) Act 1996.
In this section, costs include:
the costs of the administration of any estate or trust, and
in the case of an appeal to the court, the costs of the proceedings giving rise to the appeal, and
in the case of proceedings transferred or removed into the court, the costs of the proceedings before they were transferred or removed.

This section does not apply to proceedings in the Small Claims Division of the Local Court: see s 4 of the CPA, r 1.6 and Sch 1 of the UCPR.

Contempt proceedings: CPA Pts 3–9 (ss 19–154) only apply to civil proceedings. Proceedings initiated for the purpose of imposing punishment for “criminal contempt” are proceedings “for an offence” and are “criminal proceedings” for the purposes of CPA s 3. Consequently, CPA s 98 does not confer power to award costs in proceedings for criminal contempt: Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) v Sigalla (No 4) [2011] NSWSC 62; BC201103166 at [93]–[95] ; Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) v Sigalla (No 6) [2012] NSWSC 83; BC201201329 at [33] (the Supreme Court has an inherent power under SCA s 23 to award costs in criminal contempt proceedings). As to the distinction between “civil” and “criminal” contempt: see SCR Pt 55.0.1. As to the award of costs in civil contempt proceedings see SCR Pt 55.13.7.

level.toc-caption: [s 98.10] Costs “follow the event” — subject to any contrary provision or order

heading.title: Costs “follow the event” — subject to any contrary provision or order

p.text: The section creates a wide discretionary power. The general principle is that such a judicial power should be liberally construed and its exercise restricted only by limitations and conditions that are clearly expressed: Oshlack v Richmond River Council (1998) 193 CLR 72; 152 ALR 83; [1998] HCA 11; BC9800310 at [21] ; FAI General Insurance Co Ltd v Southern Cross Exploration NL (1988) 165 CLR 268 at 283–4, 290; 77 ALR 411; 62 ALJR 216; BC8802594 ; Emanuele v Australian Securities Commission (1997) 188 CLR 114 at 136–7; 144 ALR 359; 71 ALJR 717; BC9702205 . The only explicit limit is that the discretion to award costs is subject to the rules, and any other relevant statutory provision. Both this limit and the ordinary principle (that such a discretion must be exercised judicially) justify the proposition that costs generally follow the event: see UCPR r 42.1. Consequently, a successful party should not be deprived of costs unless there is material to justify a contrary order being made: Milne v A-G (Tas) (1956) 95 CLR 460 at 477; 30 ALJR 406; BC5600450 ; Donald Campbell & Co Ltd v Pollak [1927] AC 732 (suppression of material evidence); Berbett Pty Ltd v Hansa [1976] VR 385 . This may occur where, for example, the otherwise successful party has:
failed on substantial issues in the litigation: see [42.1.15];
caused other parties to incur unnecessary costs in their conduct of proceedings: see [42.1.20] and [42.1.25]; or
has rejected, and failed to better, reasonable offers of settlement: see generally UCPR rr 42.14 and 42.15 and related notes.

The general power is subject to the operation of any specific statutory restriction.

level.toc-caption: [s 98.12.1] Workplace Injury Management and Workers Compensation Act 1998

heading.title: Workplace Injury Management and Workers Compensation Act 1998

p.text: Various restrictions on the award of costs arise under the Workplace Injury Management and Workers Compensation Act 1998 . The thrust of these restrictions is that generally each party to proceedings for work injury damages bears their own costs. A claimant may obtain an order for party and party costs if the judgment amount is no less favourable than their final mediation offer: see eg Smith v Sydney West Area Health Service (No 2) [2009] NSWCA 62; BC200901808 (mediation and offers of compromise after work injury — costs governed by Workplace Injury Management and Workers Compensation Act 1998 s 346 and Workers Compensation Regulation 2003 regs 89–91 ); Chubs Constructions Pty Ltd v Chamma [2009] NSWCA 98; BC200903502 (appeal against costs awarded at first instance — offer made in work injury matter, no power to order indemnity costs in a claim for work injury damages).

Costs of proceedings ancillary to the claim are determined by the court rules, and are therefore subject to the general rule that costs “follow the event”. Ancillary proceedings may include interlocutory applications for particulars or discovery. They do not include proceedings for the determination of a separate question: Wilson v State Rail Authority of NSW [2009] NSWSC 1455; BC200911634 .

An appeal against a costs order made at first instance is neither a proceeding “on the claim” nor an ancillary proceeding. Each party must bear their own costs of such an appeal: Chubs Constructions Pty Ltd v Chamma (No 2) (2010) 78 NSWLR 679; [2010] NSWCA 225; BC201006440 .

The Land and Environment Court may award costs under CPA s 98 . The “follow the event” rule in UCPR 42.1 is an excluded provision in relation to proceedings in the Land and Environment Court’s class 1, 2 and 3 jurisdictions: see UCPR Sch 1; [42.1.105]. In these classes of proceedings, the LECs costs discretion is not subject to a general rule that costs should ordinarily follow the event, unless: Dillon v Gosford City Council (2011) 184 LGERA 179; 284 ALR 619; [2011] NSWCA 328; BC201108747 at [60] and following (proceedings for compensation on compulsory acquisition). The principle seems to be (at least in the context of compulsory acquisition) that a person whose land has been compulsorily acquired should be able to present an arguable case without being deterred by the prospect of being ordered to pay costs of the proceedings: Walker Corporation Pty Ltd v Sydney Harbour Foreshore Authority [2010] NSWLEC 27; BC201001087 at [35] .

The court can order indemnity costs in defamation proceedings if an unsuccessful plaintiff unreasonably failed to accept a settlement offer, and where an unsuccessful defendant unreasonably failed to make, or accept, a settlement offer. The court can also take the respective parties’ conduct of the litigation into account in exercising the costs discretion: Defamation Act s 40. These provisions operate as a significant permissive qualification on the “follow the event” rule: Haddon v Forsyth (No 2) [2011] NSWSC 693; BC201104998 at [4] ; Holt v TCN Channel Nine Pty Ltd (No 2) [2012] NSWSC 968; BC201206979 at [16] . They also depart from the provisions of the rules relating to offers of compromise (ie UCPR 42.15A) — by potentially applying to the whole of the costs of the proceedings, and not just to the costs incurred after a formal offer of compromise has been made: The purpose of these particular costs provisions is to oblige parties to defamation proceedings to take a reasonable approach to settlement negotiations: see Davis v Nationwide News Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 946; BC200808084 at [27] .

Subject to any contrary order, costs are to be assessed on the basis provided for in Legal Profession Act 2004 s 364(1) and (2) (the “ordinary basis” see CPA s 3(1) ): see r 42.2 . Where costs are ordered to be paid on an indemnity basis, the indemnity extends to all costs other than those unreasonably incurred or, on the case of a fiduciary who is entitled to an indemnity from property controlled by them, all costs other than those incurred in breach of duty: see UCPR r 42.5 . The circumstances in which costs may be ordered on an indemnity basis are considered in the notes to r 42.5 . As to orders fixing a gross sum for costs see [s 98.45]–[s 98.60] .

CPA s 98(3) and (4) permit order for the payment of a costs (either as a stated sum or as a proportion of assessed costs) at an interlocutory stage of the proceedings. This power may be exercised either as a sanction against a defaulting party (see CPA s 61(3)(f) and [2.1.20] ) or legal representative: see CPA s 99 . The power may also be exercised as a form of interim payment in favour of a plaintiff who satisfies the court of their probable success in the proceedings: Parker v Parker (1992) 16 Fam LR 458 (order in favor of a plaintiff in proceedings under the Property (Relationships) Act 1984 — order made to facilitate prosecution of the proceedings — leave to appeal refused). The applicant’s apparent prospects of success in the proceedings, and the risk of irrecoverability of any payment if they fail, are clearly material considerations in the exercise of the power: Galstian v Galstaun (bht M Chater) [2010] NSWSC 1214; BC201007803 (interim costs order refused in a contested probate suit).
Legislation cited in [s 98.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 4.3, r 42.27, r 7.2.

The court has “full power to determine by whom” costs are to be paid. Costs orders can be made against persons who are not formally parties to the proceedings: Knight v FP Special Assets Ltd (1992) 174 CLR 178 at 192–3; 107 ALR 585; (1992) 8 ACSR 1; BC9202673 ; Aiden Shipping Co Ltd v Interbulk Ltd [1986] AC 965; [1986] 2 All ER 409; [1986] 2 WLR 1051; [1986] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 117 ; New South Wales Insurance Ministerial Corp v Edkins (1998) 45 NSWLR 8; BC9805296 (NSW District Court); FPM Constructions v Council of the City of Blue Mountains [2005] NSWCA 340; BC200507704 at [198]–[219]. But it is generally only appropriate to make costs orders against the entities that are parties to the proceedings. It is the actual parties to the proceedings that have the formal powers and protections available under the litigation procedures in the legislation and rules. The parties are, in general, directly responsible for the conduct of the proceedings. They frame the issues in their pleadings and evidence. They produce the documents required by the discovery process. They serve, and are served with, affidavits and witness statements. They have the opportunity to pay into court and make offers of compromise or Calderbank offers (Calderbank v Calderbank [1976] Fam Law 93; [1975] 3 All ER 333; [1975] 3 WLR 586; [1976] Fam 93 ).

The ordinary role of the parties in conducting the proceedings indicates that particular circumstances must exist to justify an order for costs being made against a non-party: May v Christodoulou (2011) 80 NSWLR 462; [2011] NSWCA 75; BC201101949 esp at [80]–[93] (no order merely because t a director relied on UCPR r 7.2 to conduct proceedings for a corporation); Aiden Shipping Co Ltd v Interbulk Ltd (The Vimeira (No 2)) [1986] 1 AC 965 at 980; [1986] 2 All ER 409; [1986] 2 WLR 1051; [1986] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 117 per Lord Goff. This is particularly so where the conduct and result of the proceedings may have been influenced by the fact that the person took no part in them.

If an order for costs is likely to be sought against a non-party, the moving party should give early warning of their intention to seek such an order. Early warning gives the non-party an opportunity to apply to be joined as a party to the action under the rules: Vestris v Cashman (1998) 72 SASR 449 at 458; 199 LSJS 159; BC9804761 (early notice should be given of any intention to claim costs against a non-party); Symphony Group Plc v Hodgson [1994] QB 179 at 192–3; [1993] 4 All ER 143 at 152–3; [1993] 3 WLR 830 per Balcombe LJ.

Cases in which orders have been made against non-parties tend to satisfy at least some, if not a majority, of the following criteria (FPM Constructions Pty Ltd v Council of the City of Blue Mountains [2005] NSWCA 340; BC200507704 at [210] per Basten JA, with whom Beazley and Giles JJA agreed):
the unsuccessful party to the proceedings was the moving party and not the defendant;
the source of funds for the litigation was the non-party or its principal;
the conduct of the litigation was unreasonable or improper;
the non-party, or its principal, had an interest (not necessarily financial) which was equal to or greater than that of the party or, if financial, was a substantial interest, and

the unsuccessful party was insolvent or could otherwise be described as a person of straw. Whether a prior application for security for costs has been made against a non-party principal of a company, is material:

See Shawnelle Pty Ltd v SR Juice Pty Ltd (FC, Gummow J, 20 August 1993, unreported, BC9305050). However, it is always a matter of discretion: Knight v FP Special Assets Ltd (1992) 174 CLR 178 at 190–191; 107 ALR 585; 66 ALJR 560; BC9202673 . The importance of this factor being missing is necessarily diminished where any such application was unlikely to be successful: Blazai Pty Ltd v Maclarens Solicitors (No 2) [2013] NSWSC 31; BC201300315 per Adamson J (order against non-party in circumstances in which a prior security for costs application by another party had been dismissed and there was no relevant basis for suggesting that other defendants would have been successful in seeking security) at [26], [36] & [38] citing Oasis Hotel Ltd v Zurich Insurance Co (1981) 28 BCLR 230; 124 DLR (3d) 455; [1981] 5 WWR 24 at [30].
Costs orders have been against non-parties in the following circumstances:

where the proceedings constitute an abuse of process: Helljay Investments Pty Ltd v DCT (1999) 166 ALR 30; 32 ACSR 625; [1999] HCA 56; BC9906414 (reliance on an untenable constitutional issue — costs order against director of company in liquidation);

where a person’s deliberately false evidence has materially affected the conduct of proceedings: Naomi Marble & Granite Pty Ltd v FAI General Insurance Co Ltd (No 2) [1999] 1 Qd R 518; BC9800777 (costs orders made against managing director of corporate party and against a witness who also funded the litigation); Blazai Pty Ltd v Maclarens Solicitors (No 2) [2013] NSWSC 31; BC201300315 per Adamson J (sole director and shareholder of the plaintiff and its principal dishonestly fabricated documents and destroyed documents);

where the proceedings are being carried on by or for the benefit of the non-party: Bent v Gough (1992) 36 FCR 204; 108 ALR 131; BC9203543 (proceedings conducted by a liquidator); Re Land and Property Trust Co Plc [1991] 3 All ER 409; [1991] 1 WLR 601; [1992] BCC 459 (company directors); Wentworth v A-G (NSW) (1984) 154 CLR 518 at 527 (relator proceedings); Oz B & S Pty Ltd v Elders IXL Ltd (1993) 117 ALR 128; BC9304936 (company director and principal shareholder); Yates Property Corp Pty Ltd v Boland (No 2) (1997) 147 ALR 685; [1997] FCA 760; BC9703585 (company director and principal shareholder); Naomi Marble & Granite Pty Ltd v FAI General Insurance Co Ltd (No 2) [1999] 1 Qd R 518; BC9800777 (company officers); Australasian Academy of Natural Medicine Pty Ltd v Walters (2003) 85 SASR 36; 225 LSJS 477; [2003] SASC 56; BC200300558 (controller of insolvent company funded litigation);
where a solicitor has commenced proceedings without authority: Re Gardiner; Ex parte Orgill (1890) 16 VLR 641 ;

where there are proceedings between different parties arising from a common transaction or series of transactions: Aiden Shipping Co Ltd v Interbulk Ltd [1986] AC 965; [1986] 2 All ER 409; [1986] 2 WLR 1051; [1986] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 117 ;
where common questions of law arise and it is appropriate to treat some of the proceedings as test cases: Davies v Eli Lilly & Co [1987] 3 All ER 94; [1987] 1 WLR 1136 ;

where proceedings are set aside because the plaintiff (an unincorporated association) lacked capacity to commence them: R v Darlington Borough Council, Ex parte Assn of Darlington Taxi Owners (No 2) (The Times, 14 April 1994, unreported);

where the non-party has funded the litigation: Gore v Justice Corp Pty Ltd (2002) 119 FCR 429 esp at 452; 189 ALR 712; [2002] FCA 354; BC200201207 (costs order made against a litigation lender); Condliffe v Hislop [1996] 1 All ER 431 esp at 439–40; [1996] 1 WLR 753 ; Abraham v Thompson [1997] 4 All ER 362 ; 155569 Canada Ltd v 248524 Alberta Ltd (1999) 176 DLR (4th) 479 ; Dymocks Franchise Systems (NSW) Pty Ltd v Todd (No 2) [2005] 4 All ER 195; [2005] 1 NZLR 145; [2004] 1 WLR 2807; [2004] UKPC 39 (PC(UK), Nicholls, Hutton, Rodger, Brown LLJ and Dame Elias, 21 July 2004, unreported); McFarlane v E E Caledonia Ltd (No 2) [1995] 1 WLR 366; [1995] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 535 ; and

where a witness has by false evidence, or, in the case of an expert witness, by flagrant disregard of their duties to the court, caused unnecessary costs to the parties: Phillips v Symes (No 2) [2005] 4 All ER 519; [2005] 1 WLR 2043; [2005] 2 All ER (Comm) 538; [2004] EWHC 2330 (Ch) at [95] ; (this potential liability exists notwithstanding the immunity ordinarily available to witnesses who give evidence in proceedings: Mann v O’Neill (1997) 191 CLR 204 at 213; 145 ALR 682; 71 ALJR 903; BC9703256 ; Palmer v Durnford Ford (a firm) [1992] QB 483 at 487; [1992] 2 All ER 122; [1992] 2 WLR 407 ; Taylor v Director, Serious Fraud Office [1999] 2 AC 177; [1998] 4 All ER 801; [1998] 3 WLR 1040 ).

It is generally not appropriate to order a court appointed liquidator to bear the costs of unsuccessful proceedings unless they have acted improperly in the conduct of the proceedings. Merely to pursue unsuccessful proceedings will not constitute relevant impropriety unless the liquidator acted dishonestly or unreasonably: Re Beddoe; Downes v Cottam [1893] 1 Ch 547 at 562 ; Mead v Watson [2005] NSWCA 133 ; Hypec Electronics Pty Ltd (in liq) v Mead (2004) 50 ACSR 448; [2004] NSWSC 731; BC200405114 at [116] . A costs application against a liquidator could be brought under s 477(6) or s 536 Corporations Act 2001 (Cth), or in the court’s inherent jurisdiction: Arena Management Pty Ltd (recs and mgr apptd) v Campbell Street Theatre Pty Ltd (2011) 84 ACSR 33; 281 ALR 304; [2011] NSWCA 128; BC201103285 at [26] and following, esp [28], [35], [39], [41] and [42]. If the court which determines the litigation also has administrative control of the liquidation, it may consider the application against the liquidator at the end of the proceedings, provided the liquidator has been given appropriate notice of the application: Australian Forest Managers Ltd (in liq) v Bramley (1996) 65 FCR 13; 136 ALR 431 at 440–1 per Lindgren J; Kirwan v Cresvale Far East Ltd (in liq) (2002) 44 ACSR 21; (2003) 21 ACLC 371; [2002] NSWCA 395; BC200207448 at [442] per Young CJ in Eq.
Legislation cited in [s 98.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 33.11, r 5.8, r 6.23.

A non-party may appear in proceedings in various ways: under statutory provisions granting a right of appearance; under the exercise of the court’s power to permit intervention, or as an amicus curiae: see UCPR r 6.23 and the notes thereto. Unless the non-party has been granted leave to participate in the proceedings as if they were a party to the proceedings, it will rarely be appropriate to make an order for costs in their favour: Re Pan Pharmaceuticals Ltd; Selim v McGrath (2004) 48 ACSR 681; [2004] NSWSC 129; BC200400814 . Blackwood Foodland Pty Ltd v Milne [1971] SASR 403 at 411 (amicus curiae).

The court has specific powers to award costs in favour of a person who attends in answer to a subpoena: see UCPR r 33.11 ; and in favour of a person ordered to provide discovery under Pt 5: see UCPR r 5.8 .

This section confers power to award costs against the Attorney-General in relator proceedings notwithstanding other statutory provisions dealing with costs against the Crown including Claims Against the Government and Crown Suits Act 1912 (NSW) s 10 : Wentworth v Woollahra Municipal Council (No 3) (1985) 56 ALR 233; 59 ALJR 36.

Cost orders may be made, or reconsidered, at any time before the entry of final judgment. Even after the pronouncement or entry of a relevant order or judgment, costs orders may be made in relation to any outstanding application: NSW Insurance Ministerial Corporation v Edkins (1998) 45 NSWLR 8; BC9805296 . Costs orders against a non-party may also be made after the entry of judgment between the parties in the substantive proceedings: Caboolture Park Shopping Centre Pty Ltd (in liq) v White Industries (Qld) Pty Ltd (No 1) (1993) 45 FCR 224; 117 ALR 253 (costs order against legal practitioner); Akedian Co Ltd v Royal Insurance Australia Ltd [1999] 1 VR 80 at 98; BC9800417 (costs order against insurer); Dymocks Franchise Systems (NSW) Pty Ltd v Todd [2005] 4 All ER 195 (PC) (costs order against person funding litigation). Depending on the particular circumstances, variation of the costs order may be appropriate in exercise of the powers conferred by [r 36.17] (the slip rule): Roads and Traffic Authority of NSW v Palmer (No 2) [2005] NSWCA 140; BC200502986 at [25] [26] . Reconsideration of costs orders may be appropriate if they were made without giving the parties proper opportunity to make submissions about orders that should be made: Harris v Schembri (NSWSC, Bryson J, 7 November 1995, unreported, BC9501757) at pp 2B3. However a party may not apply to reopen and vary costs orders based on grounds that were not argued — either before the trial judge on any appeal: Timbarra Protection Coalition Inc v Ross Mining Ltd [1999] NSWCA 335; BC9906400 ; Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd v Marsden [1999] NSWCA 313; BC9906206 . As to the costs of interlocutory proceedings — see [42.7.5]–[42.7.20] .

level.toc-caption: [s 98.45] Limited, proportionate, and gross sum, costs orders

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 98.45] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 56(1), 57(1)(d), 60, s 98(1), s 98(4).

heading.title: Limited, proportionate, and gross sum, costs orders

p.text: The general power to award costs is stated in CPA s 98(1) in terms that emphasise the breadth of the court’s discretion. It justifies the generality that the court’s specific powers particularised in CPA s 98(4) are not confined and may be exercised whenever the circumstances warrant their exercise: Harrison v Schipp (2002) 54 NSWLR 738; BC200100344 at [21] . Nevertheless, the terms in which the s 98(4) powers are expressed, together with the more general considerations reflected in CPA ss 56(1) , 57(1)(d) and 60 (relating to reasonable proportionality between the costs of proceedings and the just determination of the matters in dispute), suggest the factors that merit particular consideration include:
the relative responsibility of the parties for the costs incurred (eg, Harrison v Schipp [2001] NSWCA 13; BC200100344 );
the degree of any disproportion between the issues litigated and the costs claimed;
the complexity of proceedings in relation to their cost;
the capacity of the unsuccessful party to satisfy any costs liability.

level.toc-caption: [s 98.50] Limited costs orders — relative responsibility of the parties

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 98.50] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 61(3)(f), s 99(1).
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 98(4)(a), (b).

heading.title: Limited costs orders — relative responsibility of the parties

p.text: Various provisions of the CPA or Rules specifically permit costs orders to be made as a sanction for either default by the parties or their legal representatives: eg, CPA s 61(3)(f) or where costs have been incurred “without reasonable cause”: see CPA s 99(1) . In addition, the general discretion in relation to costs, notwithstanding the ordinary rule that costs “follow the event” may require specific consideration not only of the respective parties’ success or failure in relation to particular issues in the proceedings: see [42.1.5]–[42.1.25] ; but also of the responsibility of the respective parties for the costs incurred in the proceedings: see eg Van Eeden v Henry (2005) 62 NSWLR 301; 42 MVR 375; [2005] NSWCA 14; BC200500882 (limited costs order where parties were separately represented in relation to their different interests in the proceedings). The powers conferred by s 98(4)(a) and (b) may be regarded as complementing these additional discretionary considerations.

level.toc-caption: [s 98.55] Proportionate costs orders — proportionality of costs

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 98.55] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 42.4.

heading.title: Proportionate costs orders — proportionality of costs

p.text: Notwithstanding the concern to achieve proportionality of costs, and the specific power conferred by r 42.4 (to fix prospectively a maximum amount for recoverable costs) the courts have been reluctant to impose arbitrary limits on the amount of costs that may be recovered in proceedings: Jvancich v Kennedy (No 2) [2004] NSWCA 397; BC200407396 (no automatic ceiling in Family Provision Act proceedings); Wentworth v Wentworth (NSWCA, Priestley, Clarke JJA and Grove AJA, 21 February 1996, unreported, BC9600215) at 34–5; Re Sherborne Estate (No 2) [2005] NSWSC 1003; BC200507645 . This is so at least in the absence of:

specific rules imposing costs recovery limits graduated according to the amount recovered (such as those previously found in SCR Pt 52A r 33 and DCR Pt 39A r 12): Motor Trade Finances Prestige Leasing Pty Ltd v Elderslie Finance Corporation Ltd [2006] NSWSC 1446; BC200611125 at [6]–[10] ($8m claim — $20,000 judgment — 75% costs awarded); Rae v Beddison Corp Pty Ltd (No 2) [2009] NSWSC 178; BC200901717 at [16]–[26] per Harrison J (proceedings within jurisdictional limits of the District Court);
an evidentiary basis for exercise of the powers referred to in the preceding paragraph of this note; or
a sufficient evidentiary basis to conclude that costs have otherwise been unnecessarily or improperly incurred.

level.toc-caption: [s 98.60] Gross and fixed sum costs orders — principles

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 98.60] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Copyright Act 1968 s 98(4).

heading.title: Gross and fixed sum costs orders — principles

p.text: Exercise of the power conferred by the CPA s 98(4) is particularly appropriate where the costs have been incurred in lengthy or complex cases and it is desirable to avoid the expense, delay and aggravation likely to be involved in contested costs assessment. That desirability may arise:

from the likely length and complexity of the assessment process: Beach Petroleum NL & Claremont Petroleum NL v Johnson (No 2) (1995) 57 FCR 119 at 120; 135 ALR 160 at 161–2; BC9507552 (4,303 page incomplete bill of costs in protracted proceedings — 7.5% discount on bill for indemnity costs, 30% discount for party/party costs); Charlick Trading Pty Ltd v Australian National Railways Commission [2001] FCA 629; BC200102744 (large costs claim related to complex dispute); Australasian Performing Rights Assoc Ltd v Marlin [1999] FCA 1006; BC9905295 ;

from the likelihood that the additional costs of formal assessment would disadvantage the successful party — because of the potential inability of the unsuccessful party to pay the costs in any event: Harrison v Schipp (2002) 54 NSWLR 738; [2002] NSWCA 213; BC2002036577 at [28]–[29] ; Sony Entertainment (Australia) Ltd v Smith (2005) 215 ALR 788; 64 IPR 18; [2005] FCA 228; BC200500963 at [190], [194]–[195] (costs ordered at 40% of the amount incurred): Hadid v Lenfest Communications Inc [2000] FCA 628; BC200002428 ; Sparnon v Apand Pty Ltd [1998] FCA 164; BC9800513 ; Hamod v NSW [2011] NSWCA 375; BC201110561 at [823]–[826] (order for payment of costs by specified lump sum — appeal dismissed);

where a party’s conduct has unnecessarily contributed to the costs of the proceedings, especially where the costs incurred have been disproportionate to the result of the proceedings: Leary v Leary [1986] 136 NLJRep 942; [1987] 1 All ER 261; [1987] 1 WLR 72 (unreasonably protracted and complex divorce proceedings); Sony Entertainment (Aust) Ltd v Smith , above at [192], (consistent procedural non-compliance by unsuccessful party); Microsoft Corp v Jiang (2003) 58 IPR 445; [2003] FCA 101; BC200300462 (party failing to appear to contest proceedings); Ireland v Retallack (No 2) [2011] NSWSC 1096; BC201107238 at [38] ff (substantial amount of factual and expert evidence — no legitimate utility in resolving dispute about construction of will — costs not reasonably incurred).

level.toc-caption: [s 98.65] Gross and fixed sum costs orders — determining the amount

heading.title: Gross and fixed sum costs orders — determining the amount

p.text: The assessment of any lump sum to be awarded must represent a review of the successful party’s costs by reference to the pleadings and complexity of the issues raised on the pleadings; the interlocutory processes; the preparation for final hearing and the final hearing: see Smoothpool v Pickering [2001] SASC 131; BC200101900 at [12] . In the exercise of the discretion the court is not required to undertake a detailed examination of the kind that would be appropriate to taxation or formal costs assessment: Harrison v Schipp (2002) 54 NSWLR 738 at 743; BC200100344 ; Hadid v Lenfest Communications Inc [2000] FCA 628; BC200002428 at [35] (the rule contemplates application of a much broader brush approach than would be applied on taxation); Auspine Ltd v Australian Newsprint Mills Ltd (1999) 93 FCR 1 at 5; [1999] FCA 673; BC9902639 (descending into the level of detail required on taxation or formal costs assessment defeats the purpose of a gross sum order).

Nevertheless, the power to award a gross sum should only be exercised when the court considers that it can do so fairly between the parties, and that includes sufficient confidence in arriving at an appropriate sum on the materials available: Wentworth v Wentworth (NSWCA, Priestley, Clarke JJA and Grove AJA, 21 February 1996, unreported, BC9600215); Harrison v Schipp, above at 743. The approach taken to estimate costs must be logical, fair and reasonable: Beach Petroleum NL & Claremont Petroleum NL v Johnson (No 2) (1995) 57 FCR 119 at 123; 135 ALR 160 at 165–6; BC9507552 ; Hadid v Lenfest Communications Inc, above at [27].

The costs ordered should be based on an informed assessment of the actual costs having regard to the information before the court (for example, by relying on costs estimates or bills): Beach Petroleum NL & Claremont Petroleum NL v Johnson (No 2) , above at FCR 124; ALR 165–6 (appropriateness of fixed cost order not contested) and at FCR 120 and 123; ALR 161–2 and 164–5 (complex proceedings — multi million dollar costs claim — order based on an incomplete bill in assessable form and interim bills rendered to clients); Leary v Leary [1986] 136 NLJRep 942; [1987] 1 All ER 261; [1987] 1 WLR 72 (unreasonably protracted and complex divorce proceedings — order based on a discounted estimate and bill); Harrison v Schipp, above at 743; Sparnon v Apand Pty Ltd [1998] FCA 164; BC9800513 (order based on expert evidence analysing interim bills and opinion about the likely outcome of taxation). It may be necessary, and it is at least desirable, for the costs claimed to involve a degree of particularity about the way in which the total costs have been calculated. This may involve evidence of the nature and amount of the rates involved. It may also involve some demonstrated connection with particular aspects of the proceedings. A merely estimated or general total of the costs claimed may not be accepted as providing a proper basis for a fixed sum costs order: Tim Barr Pty Ltd v Narui Gold Coast Pty Ltd [2011] NSWSC 11; BC201101168 at [49]–[54] per Barrett J.

Reasonable assessment of the costs incurred and properly recoverable may involve an impressionistic discount of the costs actually incurred or estimated, to take into account the contingencies that would be relevant in any formal costs assessment: Leary v Leary at WLR 76 per Purchas LJ; Beach Petroleum NL v Johnson at FCR 123; Auspine Ltd v Australian Newsprint Mills Ltd at ALR 164–5; Hamod v NSW [2011] NSWCA 375; BC201110561 at [824]–[826] (order for payment of costs by specified lump sum — appeal dismissed).

level.toc-caption: [s 98.70] Gross and fixed sum costs orders — orders by appellate courts

heading.title: Gross and fixed sum costs orders — orders by appellate courts

p.text: The exercise of specific powers to award costs in a fixed sum or as a proportion of total costs, is peculiarly within the discretion of the trial judge: Wentworth v Wentworth (NSWCA, Priestley, Clarke JJA and Grove AJA, 21 February 1996, unreported, BC9600215) at 34–5; Stebercraft Pty Ltd v Sutton “The Seapride” (NSWSC, Carruthers J, 31 March 1994, unreported). An appellate court may, of course, make a special order in circumstances where it has sufficient information at its disposal to make an order which is fair and just between the parties: Wentworth v Wentworth , above, at 35. However, an appellate court may often lack the materials necessary to allow it to attempt to assess what is a fair and just sum by way of costs, and this will provide an effective barrier to the making of such an order: Wentworth v Wentworth , above, at 35.

level.toc-caption: [s 98.75] Costs of trust or estate administration

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 98.75] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

heading.title: Costs of trust or estate administration

p.text: The costs that may be awarded under s 98(6)(a) of the CPA include the costs of administration in, or incidental to, proceedings in the court. They do not include the costs of any trust or estate administration. The distinction between the two categories of case may sometimes be difficult to make: Re Andrews [1999] 1 WLR 1236; [1999] 2 All ER 751 (receivership under specific statutory power — no power to order costs); Foord v Brock [2005] NSWCA 156; BC200506361 (investigation by administrator in pending probate proceedings — costs awarded).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [s 99] s 99 Liability of legal practitioner for unnecessary costs (cf Act No 52 1970, section 76C; SCR Part 52A, rules 43 and 43A)

leg:heading.title: Liability of legal practitioner for unnecessary costs (cf Act No 52 1970, section 76C; SCR Part 52A, rules 43 and 43A)

p.text: This section applies if it appears to the court that costs have been incurred:
by the serious neglect, serious incompetence or serious misconduct of a legal practitioner, or
improperly, or without reasonable cause, in circumstances for which a legal practitioner is responsible.
After giving the legal practitioner a reasonable opportunity to be heard, the court may do any one or more of the following:
it may, by order, disallow the whole or any part of the costs in the proceedings:
in the case of a barrister, as between the barrister and the instructing solicitor, or as between the barrister and the client, as the case requires, or
in the case of a solicitor, as between the solicitor and the client,
it may, by order, direct the legal practitioner:

in the case of a barrister, to pay to the instructing solicitor or client, or both, the whole or any part of any costs that the instructing solicitor or client, or both, have been ordered to pay to any other person, whether or not the solicitor or client has paid those costs, or
in the case of a solicitor, to pay to the client the whole or any part of any costs that the client has been ordered to pay to any other person, whether or not the client has paid those costs,
it may, by order, direct the legal practitioner to indemnify any party (other than the client) against costs payable by that party.
Before making such an order, the court may refer the matter to a costs assessor (within the meaning of Part 3.2 of the Legal Profession Act 2004) for inquiry and report.
The court may direct that notice of any proceedings or order under this section with respect to a legal practitioner be given:
in the case of a barrister, to the instructing solicitor or client, or both, as the court may direct, or
in the case of a solicitor, to the client.
The court may give ancillary directions to give full effect to an order under this section, including directions to a legal practitioner to provide a bill of costs in assessable form:
to the court, or
to a party to the proceedings, or
in the case of a barrister, to the instructing solicitor or client, or both, or
in the case of a solicitor, to the client.
A party’s legal practitioner is not entitled to demand, recover or accept:
in the case of a barrister, from the instructing solicitor or client, or
in the case of a solicitor, from the client,
any part of the amount for which the legal practitioner is directed by the court to indemnify any party pursuant to an order referred to in subsection (2)(c).
In this section, client includes former client.

heading.title: Costs incurred by serious neglect incompetence or misconduct

p.text: There is a long recognised power to order costs against a legal practitioner in cases of misconduct. The power is exercisable both in favour of the lawyer’s own client and in favour of the opposing party: Myers v Elman [1940] AC 282; [1939] 4 All ER 484 (false affidavit of discovery); Jachimowicz v Jachimowicz (1986) 10 Fam LR 566; 81 FLR 459 ; Kelly v Jowett (2009) 76 NSWLR 405; [2009] NSWCA 278; BC200908149 at [61], [62] (solicitor’s failure to prepare evidence and contest trial — appeal allowed on basis of incompetent legal representation — respondent’s costs payable by solicitors). The disjunctive references in CPA s 99(1)(a) to “serious neglect”, “serious incompetence” or “serious misconduct” nominally extend that power to situations other than those of misconduct in the strict sense. Nevertheless, all of the stated criteria require evaluation consistent with the general approach taken in Myers v Elman , above: Wentworth v Rogers [1999] NSWCA 403; BC9907174 at [41] ; Ridehalgh v Horsefield [1994] Ch 205 (the considerations discussed at [s 99.20] ).

Costs will have been incurred “improperly” where they result from conduct that would otherwise constitute professional misconduct — at least if the misconduct is “serious”: White Industries (Qld) Pty Ltd v Flower & Hart (a firm) (1998) 156 ALR 169; 29 ACSR 21; BC9803173 ; Flower & Hart (a firm) v White Industries (Qld) Pty Ltd (1999) 87 FCR 134; 163 ALR 744; [1999] FCA 773; BC9903036 ; Wentworth v Rogers [1999] NSWCA 403; BC9907174 ; Pinebelt Pty Ltd v Bagley [2000] NSWSC 655; BC200003814 ; Cahill v Ekstein (NSWSC, Smart J, No 020103/94, 5 June 1998, unreported, BC9807241); Ridhalgh v Horsfield [1994] Ch 205 at 232 . Costs may also be regarded as improperly incurred where they have been incurred contrary to the client’s express or implied instructions. Between these two extremes (of misconduct and absence of authority) the question whether costs have been properly incurred will tend to overlap with consideration of whether the costs have been reasonably incurred.
Legislation cited in [s 99.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56(3).
(NSW) Legal Profession Act 2004 ss 345, 348.

The section includes a widely expressed power to make compensatory orders against a legal practitioner who is responsible for costs having been incurred “without reasonable cause”. When read with s 56(3) and 56(4) of the CPA, the powers conferred by the present section are not confined to the jurisdiction that existed at common law: Ridhalgh v Horsfield [1994] Ch 205 at 231 ; Ireland v Retallack (No 2) [2011] NSWSC 1096; BC201107238 at [52] .

Procedural default: A legal practitioner’s duty to the court includes ensuring that proceedings are conducted efficiently and expeditiously. Conduct, including a failure to comply with the Rules or with interlocutory directions, that leads to costs being wasted or unnecessarily incurred may justify compensatory orders under the present section: Harris v Villacare Pty Ltd [2012] NSWSC 452; BC201203279 (83 page affidavit — not confined to relevant correspondence between parties — 80% of solicitor client costs — solicitor to pay 80% of other party’s costs). In addition, the court may refer conduct for investigation as to whether any breach of professional obligations has occurred: Whyte v Brosch (1998) 45 NSWLR 354 (failure to provide timely appeal submissions). But the exercise of the costs power itself does not depend on proof of actual misconduct and, in that sense, is not punitive: Pinebelt Pty Ltd v Bagley [2000] NSWSC 655; BC200003814 .

The power to order costs for “reasonable cause” permits consideration of the underlying merits of the litigation, as well as instances of procedural default. That position is made clear by the additional power, conferred by ss 345 and 348 of the Legal Profession Act 2004, to award costs against a legal practitioner who provides legal services, in relation to a “claim for damages” without a properly based belief the client has “reasonable prospects of success” in the proceedings: Keddie v Stacks/Gouldkamp Pty Ltd [2012] NSWCA 254; BC201206228 at [180] . (The expression “claim for damages” includes any proceedings in which damages are claimed, irrespective of the particular basis of the claim: Degiorgio v Dunn (No 2) (2005) 62 NSWLR 284; [2005] NSWSC 3; BC200500375 at [13] [15] ). The “reasonable prospects of success” criterion is satisfied if the claim or defence is fairly arguable: Lemoto v Able Technical Pty Ltd (2005) 2 DDCR 592; 63 NSWLR 300; [2005] NSWCA 153; BC200502983 at [1] , [12] & [132]. It does not require that a legal practitioner has a belief in the probability of the client’s success: Degorgio v Dunn (No 2) at [20]–[28].

Costs have been held to have been incurred improperly or without reasonable cause (s 99(1)(b)) where a legal practitioner has included a vast bulk of unnecessary material in an affidavit: Harris v Villacare Pty Ltd [2012] NSWSC 452; BC201203279 (90% of practitioner’s 83 page affidavit described by trial judge as a “waste of paper” which in turn necessitated a response from other party; total exchange of correspondence between parties included without any attempt to sort the relevant from the irrelevant; courts now deluged with material; 80% of costs incurred disallowed as between legal practitioner and client; legal practitioner ordered to pay 80% of other party’s costs flowing from inclusion of unnecessarily lengthy material).

level.toc-caption: [s 99.20] Discretion to award costs against legal practitioners — principles

p.text: Legislation cited in [s 99.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Legal Profession Act 2004 ss 345–348.

heading.title: Discretion to award costs against legal practitioners — principles

p.text: In so far as either the present section, or the statutory power contained in Legal Profession Act 2004 ss 345–348 , extend the power to order costs against a legal practitioner and beyond the area of serious misconduct in its most strict sense, the exercise of the power involves a balancing of two important public interests. The first is that legal practitioners should not be deterred from pursuing their clients interests by fear of personal liability to the opposing party: Degiorgio v Dunn (No 2) (2005) 62 NSWLR 284; [2005] NSWSC 3; BC200500375 at [27] . The second is that litigants should not be left to bear the costs of unjustifiable conduct — whether engaged in by their own lawyers or those of the opposing party: Ridhalgh v Horsfield [1994] Ch 205 at 226 . The reconciliation of these two important public interests dictates the result that the costs sanction authorised by both the present section and similar statutory provisions, remains a matter of discretion, even where the factual bases for its exercise have been established: Lemoto v Able Technical Pty Ltd (2005) 2 DDCR 592; 63 NSWLR 300; [2005] NSWCA 153; BC200502983 at [92], [135]–[138] (power to be sparingly and only in clear cases).

heading.title: Rights and obligations in relation to difficult cases

p.text: In relation to the first principle, it is clear that a legal practitioner ought not be subjected to liability under the present section merely because the proceedings are likely to fail: Rondel v Worsley [1969] 1 AC 191 at 275 ; Ridhalgh v Horsfield , above, at 233; Orchard v South Eastern Electricity Board [1987] QB 565 at 572; [1987] 1 All ER 95 ; Arundel Chiropractic Centre Pty Ltd v DCT (2001) 179 ALR 406 at 413; [2001] HCA 26; BC200102181 per Callinan J; Gore v Justice Corp Pty Ltd (2002) 119 FCR 429 esp at 439; 189 ALR 712; [2002] FCA 354; BC200201207 ; Ironaid Pty Ltd v Tsatsoulis (NSWSC, Bryson J, 7 June 1996, unreported, BC9602365); Harley v McDonald [2001] 2 AC 678; [2002] 1 NZLR 1 (practitioner acting on client’s express instructions); Whyked Pty Ltd v Yahoo!7 Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 477; BC200804072 at [182]–[186] (impecunious plaintiff — claim not manifestly hopeless — solicitor acting in accordance with counsel’s advice and reasonable personal attention). However the power to impose a costs sanction may be enlivened if the proceedings are either “futile or foredoomed to fail”: Lemoto v Able Technical Pty Ltd at [102]–[111]; if the proceedings constitute a deliberate abuse of process: White Industries (Qld) Pty Ltd v Flower & Hart (a firm) (1998) 156 ALR 169; 29 ACSR 21; BC9803173 (abuse of process); Edwards v Edwards [1958] P 235 at 248; [1958] 2 All ER 179 ; Cahill v Ekstein (NSWSC, Smart J, No 020103/94, 5 June 1998, unreported, BC9807241) (proceedings with no prospect of success); or where the proceedings are pursued without any belief they had any prospect of success: Steindl Nominees Pty Ltd v Laghaifar [2003] 2 Qd R 683; [2003] QCA 157; BC200301794 (improper to pursue proceedings believed to be bound to fail).

heading.title: Obligation to have regard to prospects of success

p.text: In relation to the second principle, an award of costs against a legal practitioner is plainly justified where a legal practitioner:
conducts proceedings without authority from the client: Yonge v Toynbee [1910] 1 KB 215 at 225–8 and at 231; Myers v Elman [1940] AC 282; [1939] 4 All ER 484 ;
relies on untenable defences for the mere purpose of delaying the proceedings: Deputy Cmr of Taxation v Levick (1999) 168 ALR 383; 43 ATR 621 ;

is responsible for objectively untenable claims or defences being made: Pinebelt Pty Ltd v Bagley [2000] NSWSC 655; BC200003814 (costs of caveat proceedings ordered against a barrister who assisted in the preparation of an insupportable caveat);
allows an unqualified client to assume the effective conduct of the proceedings: Wentworth v Rogers [1999] NSWCA 403; BC9907174 at [47] (solicitor);

is responsible for costs wasted as a result of a legal practitioner’s failure to prepare evidence for, and effectively conduct, trial proceedings: Kelly v Jowett (2009) 76 NSWLR 405; [2009] NSWCA 278; BC200908149 at [61], [62] .

is responsible for costs wasted as a result of a legal practitioner’s ignorance of, and failure to comply with, the relevant rules: Riv-Oland Marble Co (Vic) Pty Ltd v Settef Spa (1989) 63 ALJR 519 ; although mere procedural default is not necessarily sufficient to justify a personal costs sanction against a legal practitioner: Leicester v Walton (NSWCA, Priestley, Sheller and Cole JJA, 22 November 1995, unreported, BC9501770) (failure to give notice on ceasing to act — consequential adjournment and delay — no costs order).

Apart from such instances the general position is that, provided the client is properly advised, it is the client, not the legal practitioner who is responsible for deciding what costs are appropriate to incur in connection with the conduct of the proceedings. If the proviso (of proper advice) is not satisfied, costs may be awarded against a legal practitioner where costs have been incurred without reasonable justification: Blake v Norris (NSWSC, Hulme J, 3 July 1997, unreported, BC9702879) (costs incurred in providing unnecessary information and instructions to expert witnesses) following Knaggs v JA Westaway & Sons Pty Ltd (1996) 40 NSWLR 476 at 484–5 .
